TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Sandy-skeletal, mixed Typic Cryorthents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Canlodore very cobbly loamy sand-woodland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
Oe--1 inch to 0; partially decayed needles and twigs. (1 to 2 inches thick)
E--0 to 6 inches; pinkish gray (7.5YR 7/2) very cobbly loamy sand, pinkish gray (7.5YR 6/3) moist; weak coarse granular structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; 20 percent pebbles, 15 percent cobbles, 5 percent stones; moderately acid (pH 6.0); clear smooth boundary.  (5 to 12 inches thick)
EB--6 to 17 inches; pink (7.5YR 7/4) very cobbly loamy sand; light brown (7.5YR 6/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; 20 percent pebbles, 20 percent cobbles, 5 percent stones; slightly acid (pH 6.2); gradual smooth boundary.  (0 to 12 inches thick)
Bw--17 to 27 inches; reddish yellow (7.5YR 6/6) very cobbly loamy sand, strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; 20 percent pebbles, 20 percent cobbles, 5 percent stones; slightly acid (pH 6.2); gradual smooth boundary.  (0 to 15 inches thick)
BC--27 to 39 inches;  reddish yellow (7.5YR 7/6) very cobbly sand, reddish yellow (7.5YR 6/6) moist; single grain; loose, nonsticky and nonplastic; 25 percent pebbles, 30 percent cobbles, 5 percent stones; slightly acid (pH 6.2); gradual smooth boundary.  (0 to 15 inches thick)
C--39 to 60 inches;  pink (7.5YR 7/4) very cobbly sand, light brown (7.5YR 6/4) moist; single grain; loose, nonsticky and nonplastic; 25 percent pebbles, 30 percent cobbles, 5 percent stones; slightly acid (pH 6.2).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Moffat County, Colorado; about 33 miles west of Powderwash; about 2,600 feet north and 2,300 feet east of the southwest corner of Sec. 22, T. 12 N., R. 103 W.; 108 degrees, 57 minutes, 50 seconds west longitude; 40 degrees, 59 minutes, 09 seconds north latitude.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature is 39 to 42 degrees F.  The mean summer soil temperature is 45 to 47 degrees F.  The control section is 35 to 60 percent rock fragments.
The E horizon has a hue is 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 6 or 7 dry, 5 or 6 moist, and a chroma of 2 or 3.  This horizon may or may not meet the requirements of an albic horizon.
The B horizon, when present, has a hue is 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 5 or 6, and a chroma of 4 through 6.  Reaction is moderately acid or slightly acid.  This horizon is absent in some pedons.
The C horizon has a hue is 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 6 or 7 dry, 5 or 6 moist, and a chroma of 3 or 4.  Texture is very cobbly loamy sand or very cobbly sand.  Reaction is moderately acid or slightly acid.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Alflack (WY), Castlepeak (T)(ID), Chena (AK), Chenega (T)(AK), Cryomont (T)(WY), Graylock (ID), Howardsville (T)(CO), Mirror Lake (UT), Nataga (AK), Nizina (AK), Obscurity (WA), Ovando (MT), Polepatch (WA), Stecum (MT), and Studebaker (WA) series.  Alflack, Castlepeak, Chena, Chenega, Cryomont, Graylock, Howardsville, Nataga, Nizina, Obscurity, Polepatch, Stecum, and Studebaker do not have E horizons.  Ovando soils contain lamellae.  Alflack soils also have bedrock at a depth of 20 to 40 inches.  Mirror Lake soils have strong or very strongly acid soil reactions in the Bw and C horizons.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Canlodore soils are on mountainsides.  Slopes range from 15 to 40 percent.  The soils formed in glacial deposits derived from sandstone and quartzite.  The mean annual precipitation ranges from 18 to 20 inches.  The mean annual air temperature ranges from 37 to 40 degrees F.  The frost-free period is 50 to 75 days.  Elevation ranges from 7,000 to 9,200 feet.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Davtone, Libeg, and Muggins soils.  The Davtone and Libeg soils have mollic epipedons and argillic horizons.  The Muggins soil has an argillic horizon and is in a fine family.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; slow runoff; rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for timber production and wildlife habitat.  Vegetation consists of lodgepole pine with an understory of spike trisetum, blue wildrye, heartleaf arnica, elk sedge, and common juniper.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Canlodore soils are in northwestern Colorado and possibly adjacent parts of Wyoming.  The series is of small extent.  Total acreage is about 7,000 acres.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Moffat County (Moffat County Area), Colorado, 1991.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  An albic horizon is recognized in this pedon - the zone from 0 to 6 inches.  Last updated by the state 12/90.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
